fields.body:
Ten years ago, when Netflix was just a DVD mail-order business based in California, co-founder Reed Hastings vowed to built the “leading company” in the then-emerging online consumer entertainment business.

Last week figures from the TV ratings body Barb showed Hastings’ vision had become reality in the UK. Barb estimated that more than 5m British homes subscribed to Netflix in 2015, compared with 1.6m for rivals Amazon Prime Instant Video and fewer than 1m for Sky’s internet service Now TV.

Related: Netflix races ahead of Amazon and Sky with 5m UK households

That means Netflix is now in nearly a quarter of UK households, with 1.4m joining the streaming service in 2015 alone to watch hit series such as the political thriller House of Cards. Business research company IHS forecasts Netflix will have about 7.5m subscribers in the UK by 2019.

With a market cap of about $42bn (£29bn) and 75 million subscribers, Netflix has a presence in about 200 countries. Arguably it is the first global broadcaster, despite being an internet streaming service.

Netflix’s programming budget matches its global ambition and reach. In 2016, it plans to spend about $5bn on content, up from $3bn last year. Investment bank UBS estimates Netflix’s UK content spend at about €360m (£283m) for this year, rising to €409m annually over the next four years.

Richard Eary, the UBS head of European media equity research, says: “Based on our forecasts we expect Netflix will spend more on content globally than the top seven commercial broadcasters in Europe by 2018-19.”

Jonathan Broughton, a IHS senior analyst for TV, television media, agrees Netflix is “outspending everyone else currently on content and, if you take a global total, excluding sport, that includes Sky”.

Most of the content budget for on demand services such as Netflix and Amazon is spent on rights to libraries of other people’s programmes, which means they have to bid for the rights in each individual market.

However, the ability to aggregate the costs across many countries means it makes business sense – owing to economies of scale – to invest in scripted drama, despite its high cost.

Although it began as a library of other people’s shows and benefited, in particular, by marketing itself as the online home of the critically lauded US drama Breaking Bad, Netflix’s decision to invest in its own original programmes took it to another level. The success of the 2013 remake of Andrew Davies’ BBC adaptation of Michael Dobbs’ novel House of Cards, starring Kevin Spacey, became its calling card.

Netflix became synonymous with the concept of binge-viewing after settling on a strategy of releasing all the episodes of its new shows at once, globally, taking the moreish habits already established with DVD box sets online.

The company has “surfed the zeitgeist” of immersive viewing, according to Radio Times editor Ben Preston. “We’re watching television in a way now that we read books – you immerse yourself in a world 20 hours at a time and the Scandinavians kick-started all that with The Killing telling the story of a murder over 20 hours with subtitles.

“Netflix absolutely caught on to that with House of Cards, Orange is the New Black ... They turned immersive cinema into something you could do in your own living room.”

The company has allied its investment in original programming with tentpole marketing, using the popularity of series such as House of Cards to promote its wider content offering. “Nothing is as powerful as a big hit,” says Preston, “and they’ve had a string of shows which got people talking”, the latest of which is Making a Murderer.

Original programming output will rise from 450 hours last year to 600 in 2016. Netflix is reportedly splashing out about £100m on The Crown, its first UK original drama, an epic royal biopic based on Peter Morgan’s play The Audience and starring Wolf Hall’s Claire Foy and former Doctor Who Matt Smith.

Other big names making shows for the international streaming service include Brad Pitt, Will Smith, Ricky Gervais and Charlie Brooker, whose dystopian drama Black Mirror is transferring from Channel 4.

Behind the showbiz hoopla is also a sophisticated technology, commercial and marketing strategy that has helped drive the popularity of the service in the UK.

Broughton says one of the reasons for Netflix’s success in the UK is that culturally viewers are used to “paying quite a lot for television” via providers such as Sky or Virgin, so “a low price point of £5.99 is extremely encouraging for them to take up an additional pay TV on the back of what they have”.

He adds that the BBC helped as the iPlayer “trained people” in how to consume TV shows online. Good broadband penetration in the UK has also helped, plus the fact that we share the same language as the US-based Netflix.

Watching Netflix also does not require a monthly contract, arguably disrupted the market – and future generations of viewers’ expectations of long-term contracts – especially for Sky, which launched its own more expensive no-contract internet service Now TV in 2012.

They are not completely directly comparable as Now TV offers a full TV service whereas “Netflix is a VOD library”, Broughton says, adding that marketing has come into play as Sky went with a fresh brand, thus “protecting their pay TV business” but costing more to market from a standing start.

fields.standfirst: Company has left Amazon and Sky trailing in online entertainment sector – notching up 5m UK subscribers – and plans to spend $5bn on original content
